Award.AwardTitle: SHF: Medium: Collaborative Research: Improved Performance Testing and Debugging

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Software performance is critical for how end users perceive the quality of the deployed software. Performance problems, also called "performance bugs", typically correspond to software faults that create significant performance degradation. Much evidence shows that seemingly harmless performance problems can lead to severe scalability reductions and financial losses. This project develops a set of new techniques and tools that can significantly improve performance testing and debugging.

Specifically, the project focuses on three key challenges. First, what are common patterns of performance bugs and how can these patterns be detected during testing, before they manifest in production runs? Second, how to ensure that code changes for adding new features, fixing bugs, or even improving performance do not have unintended consequence of decreasing performance? Third, how to find causes of performance bugs from testing runs, regression checks, and in-field execution traces? The broader impacts of the project are that improved performance testing and debugging can substantially increase the quality of the deployed software and thus the quality of life in a modern society that heavily depends on software.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Software performance is critical for how end users perceive the quality of the deployed software. Performance problems, also called "performance bugs", typically correspond to software faults that create significant performance degradation. Much evidence shows that seemingly harmless performance problems can lead to severe scalability reductions and financial losses. The goal of this project was to develop new techniques and tools that can substantially improve performance testing and debugging. This project was a collaborative effort, involving the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign (NSF award number CCF-1409423) and the University of California, Irvine (NSF award number CCF-1409829).

This project developed several techniques and tools that can help improve various kinds of software systems, including the following contributions: (1) performance improvements for parallel and distributed applications, (2) performance improvements for big data applications, (3) improvements for mobile applications, (4) improvements for various Internet-of-Things domains, (5) advances in program analysis, (6) improved support for debugging, and (7) general advances in software testing and engineering. In sum, the project found that (i) performance problems widely exist in various application domains, and (ii) the techniques developed in this project can help to substantially improve the performance and scalability for a variety of important applications and systems, enabling them to process data more efficiently and scale to larger datasets.

The two collaborative NSF awards partially supported a total of 57 publications (in journals, main and specialized tracks of conferences, and workshops), public release of several software tools and datasets (some available from http://mir.cs.illinois.edu page on software and data), and training of over a dozen graduate students (directly supported by the awards or collaborating on the project) and a dozen of undergraduate students (of whom some co-authored papers or contributed to open-source code). The broader impacts also include reporting numerous bugs in various open-source software projects. Overall, this research is a step toward better support for performance testing and debugging in several software domains of growing importance.
